comments.commentBody: I also bought a Dell back in 2004 and it mysteriously died on me a year and half later. I am sure many more were affected than the companies mentioned in the article. I wonder why no lawyer has filed a class-action lawsuit on behalf of the millions who bought faulty PCs from Dell. Its easy to know since Dell tracks all the parts sold per computer by serial#.

Since I prefer to buy American built brands but sadly I've had to buy into the Chinese built models of machines and parts.

Nichicon provided the capacitors which also contain some very nasty chemicals but if you go to http://www.nichicon.co.jp... and look at NICHICON ELECTRONICS (TIANJIN) CO., LTD. and FPCAP ELECTRONICS (SUZHOU) CO., LTD. plus another those two listed in () show that they're both Chinese capacitor manufacturers.

Obviously Six Sigma skips these folks.

two years ago at great personal expense (I'm a single mother) I purchased three laptop computers from Dell for my children - triplets, and at that time - high school seniors.  I mistakenly believed I was making an investment for their upcoming college years - and I was sold a bundle of extras that to this date have been mostly useless - big bulky printers were "included" (instead of a built in webcam, for example).  The printers sit unused, and unfortunately are incompatible with anything but these exact dell laptops.  All three laptops have been consistently having battery breakdowns, I feel as if I threw away my one chance to give my kids something they really needed.  I will never purchse anything from Dell Computers again.

Seems that Apple suffered the same problem with faulty capacitors. My four year old iMac died when a number of its capacitors failed, causing the logic board to fail. Rather than spend $900 to replace the logic board for the iMac, I decided to purchase a second MacBook Pro. I am a highly enthusiastic Apple customer and will continue to be. For the record, I did email Apple (Steve Jobs to be specific, as I had heard that he has, on many occasions, helped to offset replacement costs). No cigar!!
Fwiw, I bought an XPS m1330 laptop from Dell 2 years ago and it is the best laptop I have ever used.  It is simply a joy to operate.  I thought someone might want to hear from a happy customer.
Love the HiTech bungee cord on the steering wheel.  Just a few bugs to work out.

IIf Arizona were serious about illegal aliens in their state, they would have passed a law to crack-down on businesses that create the demand for their exploited labor.

America understands which party will scapegoat minorities at first opportunity for political populism. The GOP's brownshirt brigade, the Tea Party, is hellbent to find someone to blame for the messes they themselves helped to create.
I only bought a Dell monitor once and I could not boot my computer because of it. It was the last Dell product I will purchase.

Right now I'm reading "The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest" by Stieg Larsson. As most of you probably know, it's currently #1 on the hardcover fiction bestseller list. And I'm reading it for free. No, I didn't steal it. A few months ago, in anticipation of the publication date, I entered an online request on my library's website. A few days after the books was available, I got a call that the book was waiting for me to pick it up. So unlike all you Kindle/iPad/Nook/etc. people, I never have to complain about the price. I also read a lot of old mysteries which are not available in ebook format at any price.
Ten years ago, Mr. Dell suggested that Apple close its doors and give the money back to its stockholders. Perhaps Mr. Dell should take his own advice.

The problems continue for Dell. I have a brand new Studio XPS sitting on the floor of my office with either hard drive failure or mother board failure. It did not work out of the box. E-mails and calls to sales support are a crap shoot sometimes helpful, sometimes evasive. Tech lines can be unproductive and e-mails take days, days to get answered. The XPS is supposed to be replaced (phone confirmation) but I have no e-mail confirmation that it will be only a promise. I agree with earlier post about upselling. I would have been happy with the sound system speced with original order but was offered an upgrade by phone salesperson for no charge. Ya, no charge until you get your credit card bill and see the speakers listed and charged to you. Dell says too bad, they were not listed in the build sheet and we have no evidence of the offer. You can keep them or send them back but we will not give you your original sound system. Bait and switch, upselling, call it what you will but this is not the company it once was.

Funny, I had a dell around this time and had to have my motherboard replaced 4 times by them- good thing I had an extended warranty but was still a huge inconvenience.  I will never buy a dell again or recommend it to anyone and am happy about this lawsuit.  At least some good comes out of over-litigiousness!

This is the kind of problem that is supposed to be headed off by procurement, component engineering and QA. Any competent electronic equipment manufacturer should know how to do sampling, accelerated lifetime testing, parametric testing, physical analysis and so on in the context of statistical process control. When something like this happens, it speaks to senior management looking to save a few buck by cutting back on the kinds of folks that do those things. Of course, the million or so they saved in headcount nowhere near covers the risk associated with problems like this.

Unfortunately, managers in many companies have become short sighted and obsessed with cost cutting without regard to the value of what was cut. Add to this the fact that reputable suppliers are being undercut by fly-by-night operations in southern China, and you have a recipe for systemic failure.

I hope that this becomes a case study in Harvard Business Review.
I am confused. Wouldn't a capacitor that is bulging actually have more capacity?

Apparently Dell's component problem did not end in 2005. I bought a Vostro in February 2009. In 10 months 2 hard drives and a motherboard failed. While they did replace the faulty parts it cost down time and lost work product. They were willing to attempt to retrieve data from the fried hard drive (2 weeks after I got it.) for a measly $1000 or so. I now back up things online automatically. I don't think I will be buying another Dell.

I too will not buy from Dell again. 10 years ago I had no issues; my last top of the line was so much trouble I gave up after 2 years of constant complaining and emailing. Switched to Apple and will never go back to PC again; life is too short. Pity though, it had a great history and romantic origin. Join the dodo Dell.
Dell's 260s, 270s, and 280s have been nothing but headaches for me at my job. What the motherboards were to these, are what the power supplies are to the 620's. Hoping we can switch to HP soon...

you get what you pay for.

Cheap Dell = raw deal.

I have followed the flying car idea for too many years to get over-excited, but this one at least seems to show promise ... Computerised other vehicle avoidance systems (GPS based?) MUST be mandatory in them all though for the idiots safety, let alone mine!

I have little sympathy for all those people who bashed Apple while proclaiming that Dell was the state-of-the-art in computer town.

They were so arrogant in their belief that a cheap computer would displace something better that works, simply because it cost less.

What's Dell trading at now? How long has it been since Dell shareholders saw a profit?

What has Dell done lately to advance in the tech sector?

>>ORLANDO, Florida--When it comes to the state of Apple Computer, everyone has an opinion.

And at the Gartner Symposium and ITxpo97 here today, the CEO of competitor Dell Computer added his voice to the chorus when asked what could be done to fix the Mac maker. His solution was a drastic one.

"What would I do? I'd shut it down and give the money back to the shareholders," Michael Dell said before a crowd of several thousand IT executives.<<

We have dumped both Dell & Microsoft. Nowadays we use ASUS notebooks, custom built PC's (with plenty of spare components) & Linux.

As for the capacitors, most in the industry understand that it was Chinese espionage agaisnt the Taiwanese, whom knowing this, leaked faked capacitor data to the Chinese, hence we have millions of failing capacitors in the international marketplace.

There was that swell flying car that was supposed to be in a James Bond film...until the wings came off in mid-flight. The filmmakers, undaunted used a model. The contraption was dubbed (catchily) the AVE Mizar. On Sept.11, 1973, one of the wings folded up in mid-flight over the San Fernando Valley. I have often wondered what the two occupants of the Mizar were thinking as they plummeted to their deaths. They were, you see, the president and VP of the company, the two people who were the most convinced that this was a good idea. Oh, and the car they used? A Ford Pinto.

I wonder what happens in this car/plane if you hit that wing-folding button in mid-flight? I'm sure that nothing could possibly go wrong.

I've owned several Dell computers and never had a single problem with any of them, never had to call customer service, no warranty claims, nothing.
However my company works with Apple laptops & desktops, VERY expensive and they're nothing but trouble!

About 18 months ago I bought a dell laptop which was pretty much a top of the line unit.....It crapped out after about 5 months latter and called customer service which was in India of course......After running about 5 or 6 diagnostics over several weeks and getting nowhere and promises of return phone calls by "managers" since I was getting nowhere I eventually got someone who told me to remove the hard drive and examine it......I had an extra warranty and if I followed their instructions I would have nullified the warranty by making Unauthorized repairs and would be in breach of the warranty......I have made at least 10 more calls and been left on hold for unbelievable time periods and got nowhere with promised call backs.....I got on another computer (not a Dell thank god} and looked up Rip off reports on Dell and its truly a revelation to see the number of rip offs that this corporation has perpetrated on the buyers of their products......I gave up in disgust and resigned myself to a $1000 loss but now in the light of this article I intend to sue in small claims court and if unsuccessful will drive to Texas and personally throw it through Micheal Dells house window with full press and tv coverage and to hell with the consequences.....I have had it up to here with this rip off company and its Indian stall and evade tactics until you give up..... tactics which are deliberate company policy direct from Michael himself no less!
I've used Dell computers at work and home for about 12 years now and never had any problems with them.  I really like their chassis design and their web based support has been good too.
